sections: Twitter is still fundamentally the same product I started using nearly 15 years ago. The heart of the service is a stream of size-limited text messages from people you follow. Many of the innovations we‚Äôve come to associate with the product ‚Äî like @replies and retweets ‚Äî were actually created by users. That timeline has been tweaked, you can shove more kinds of stuff into it now, and the sort of apps we use to access it have changed over the years.
But it‚Äôs recognisably the same company, doing the same thing.
That‚Äôs in the process of changing. Two pieces of news this week give us the outline of where it‚Äôs going, and I want to take a little time to dig into that, and why we should be paying attention.
Twitter‚Äôs audio rooms are now available to
, a startup based around delivering a better, paid news reading experience to customers.

They point towards a new vision of Twitter. The feed remains central to what it does, but around it are a set of tools that make it easier for users to consume articles and newsletters from creators, and to engage with them in other ways on the platform. Equally, creators who are good at building an audience and keeping their attention on the platform will have new ways to turn that attention into cold, hard cash.

Many platforms have launched themselves off the back of the graph of connections we build on Twitter. Meerkat and Medium did it, and even Substack used high attention followers as a signal to reach out to people with Substack Pro deals. Now ‚Äî finally ‚Äî Twitter is getting in on that game itself.

Twitter has made Spaces ‚Äî its Clubhouse-like audio room feature ‚Äî available to anyone with over 600 followers. This is exciting, as I finally get to play with it usefully. I have four Twitter accounts, and only one of them had access to the feature ‚Äî the account I never use.

This has potential as a great audience engagement tool, if you already have an active following on the bird site. Big news event happens, go live quickly and easily to discuss it with your followers, building that connection with them, and reinforcing your title as the go-to place for these discussions.

The advantage that Twitter has here is that people are already on Twitter, and can easily jump into the session, by popping their headphones on. With Clubhouse, you have to actively move people over there. Right now, if you want to do more with your followers, generally you need to push them out of Twitter, and into another app (and yes, I‚Äôm counting the web as another app in that). Occasionally, that‚Äôs desirable ‚Äî we build a lot of audience engagement on the ability to do that. But equally, we just want to quickly engage with our audience around a key topic ‚Äî and this is a new tool for delivering that.
Meanwhile, Clubhouse‚Äôs hype bubble is deflating pretty quickly. Downloads have dropped from 10 m in February to
. That‚Äôs not as bad as it looks ‚Äî at 10 m downloads a month, you run out of people pretty quickly. But equally, to see growth slowing as competitors emerge is something to watch.

There is, of course, a serious question about the long-term future of the app. After all, the early mobile video live-streaming apps, Periscope and Meerkat, are long gone. Clubhouse could easily suffer the same fate.

Look at it this way: for most people broadcast live video is a tool, not an app. If you want to go live, you go to Facebook or YouTube. However, if you want to build a community and become known for your streaming, you head to Twitch or Discord. That‚Äôs the way live audio is heading: for most of us, we‚Äôll go live on Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn, depending on where we have the connections, and who we‚Äôre trying to reach. Clubhouse will have to turn itself into the Twitch of the live audio space.
Live audio: a tool and a destination?

Meanwhile, I‚Äôm really looking forward to seeing what people do with Twitter spaces. Here in the UK, we‚Äôre in the midst of a big election day. It‚Äôs not a general election, but there are enough votes across the country that it‚Äôs going to be taken as a measure of the political landscape right now.
hoping to see some interesting Spaces pop up late in the evening, and into tomorrow as the results come in. After all, nobody owns the intersection of journalism and politics like Twitter‚Ä¶
All of this, amusingly, puts Twitter back into the audio game. What do I mean by ‚Äúback‚Äù? Well, the company that is now Twitter had its roots in a
called Odeo, that was founded by Ev Williams after he sold Blogger to Google. I thoroughly recommend the book
by Nick Bilton if you want to know that story.
Twitter acquires Scroll and kills Nuzzel

Talking of Ev Williams, it‚Äôs clear since Twitter acquired the email platform Revue that it‚Äôs building towards a future as a marketplace. The main Twitter feed is a place where readers can discover creators

consume their work ‚Äî and those creators can derive revenue from that. William‚Äôs Medium seemed like an obvious play to build value around a Twitter following, but after numerous pivots, the link between the two platforms is all but broken. Time for Twitter to do that itself.

The news that Twitter has bought Scroll, a service that attempted to provide a better rendering experience and revenue to publishers, is a key step towards that revised vision of Twitter. It‚Äôs another piece of the toolset that will make it the best place for creators and consumers of written content to meet.

This is all rather disconcerting: social media acquisitions used to be all about the team, or killing competition, but to see Twitter acquiring a coherent set of tools that could radically expand the utility of the core product?
News as part of your Twitter subscription

Scroll was and is a good idea: charge readers $5 per month, and distribute that among partner publishers whose content they consume. Now, that‚Äôs going to be part of Twitter‚Äôs forthcoming subscription offering:

As a Twitter subscriber, picture getting access to premium features where you can easily read articles from your favourite news outlet or a writer‚Äôs newsletter from Revue, with a portion of your subscription going to the publishers and writers creating the content.
This has some resonance with Apple News and similar services: it will be

. They‚Äôll still want direct relationships with their most engaged readers, and to develop out their audience revenue models. But this is a way of deriving revenue from people who will never become your direct supporters.
Scroll couldn‚Äôt get enough traction with this idea on its own. As the Scroll blog post on the acquisition put it:

However, we‚Äôre not moving fast enough. Every journalist that loses their job, every newsroom sold to unworthy owners diminishes the great conversation of which we are a part. That is why, when Twitter approached us about accelerating our mission we began to get very, very excited.
, there‚Äôs still some resistance to the idea of these sorts of services:

A lot has to do with the media industry and its bureaucratic disfunction. The fact remains that destination viewing of media is becoming a habit only reserved for a fading generation of readers. Discovery, distribution, and consumption of media have taken on a different meaning. And believe it or not ‚Äî Twitter is smack in the middle of this Venn diagram.

Nuzzel: requiem for a power-user tool
However, there is one casualty of the deal. Today, Nuzzel dies, and I mourn it.

It was a simple idea, gracefully executed. Peek into the Twitter API (and LinkedIn and Facebook, too), look for links being shared by people you follow, and rank them by number of shares in your network. It was an insanely time-efficient way of catching up with important news, the 21st century equivalent of a cuttings service.

On days when I didn‚Äôt have the time to pay attention to Twitter, it was invaluable to me: I could open it and find out which links were getting the most traction in my network, and quickly catch up on the things I needed to know. It made Twitter a valuable resource to me, even when I wasn‚Äôt reading or posting there much.
And it‚Äôs dead. And I grieve.
I‚Äôm far from alone. John Gruber
It‚Äôs a remarkably effective way to find good articles. If I had to guess, I‚Äôd say I‚Äôve posted thousands of linked list items here on Daring Fireball that discovered via Nuzzel over the years.
He‚Äôs also rounded up some quote from tech industry types who will miss it. Two newsletters I used to read regularly ‚Äî
‚Äôs ‚Äî were powered by it, but both have switched to Twitter-owned Revue ‚Äî and a more manual and time-intensive caution process, I would imagine.
However, there is a glimmer of hope. Here‚Äôs Tony Haile, CEO of Scroll, which had acquired Nuzzel some years ago,

For some of us ‚Äî the news power-users and creators ‚Äî that would be a service worth the Twitter subscription fee on its own.
